text:
“He’s got round her,” Nastasya murmured, smiling slyly.

“Why don’t you put the sugar in your tea, Nastasya?” 

“You are a one!” she giggled. “I’m not Nikiforovna, but Petrovna.”

Razumihin chuckled. “I planned an explosion to uproot all malignant influences. But Pashenka won the day.”

Raskolnikov said nothing, eyes full of alarm.

“Ah, the sly dog!” Nastasya shrieked, delighted.

“It’s a pity you didn’t approach her differently. You let her stop sending your dinner.”

Raskolnikov shifted uncomfortably.

“And that I O U? Mad to sign it! And that promise of marriage?” 

Nastasya laughed again. “But Praskovya Pavlovna isn’t nearly so foolish.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin discusses the complexities of a woman's character and Raskolnikov's past decisions regarding her.
